Award.AwardTitle: An Integrated View on Neural Correlates of Attention and Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research to study how electrical activities in neuronal circuits give rise to intelligent control behaviors from perception to action. The approach is to first record behavioral and neurophysiological data from a rat while he performs a driving task. Subsequently the experimental data will be analyzed using spatiotemporal coding schemes and phase coherence techniques to unveil the correlation between neural cortical signals and behavior. The PI will perform multichannel chronic recordings from rat?s motor and premotor areas and posterior parietal cortex using a combination of Electrocorticography electrodes and depth electrodes for single unit activities.


Intellectual merit. The proposed research is a systematic approach to addressing fundamental issues in relation to the integration of perception and control, neural coding/decoding, and the causal relationship between neural representations and intelligent behaviors.

Broad impact. The proposed experiments are challenging and thus, results from these studies can be potentially ground breaking. This study is a part of the PI?s long term goal of pushing toward an understanding of natural and complex behaviors, which is a significant step forward from what are currently available in experimental and computational neuroscience. Fundamental discoveries from this research can provide important insights on nano-circuits designed to replace or provide remedy for deficient neural circuits in patients with perceptual-motor impairment. Graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, many of whom are female, have been and will continue to be involved in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to conduct experimental and computational studies to address the question of how electrical activities in neuronal circuits give rise to intelligent control behaviors, especially during the time course from attention to control execution. As such, this project serves as a fundamental step to serve the scientific community by establishing a new rat-robot driving experiment to enable the study and to elucidate the fundamental mechanisms of rat neural representation in the frontal cortical areas and parietal areas.

Through the course of this research, we have successfully conducted the proposed research, which includes 1) setting up the experimental apparatus, 2) training rats for the behavioral task, 3) implanting five rats who participated in the experiment, and 4) collecting neural and behavioral data from all five rats, at least three of which  rendered good neural and behavioral data. The three datasets were complete, in good condition, and thus are readily useful for data scientists. They are organized, format checked, behavioral event synchronized, well documented, and saved. The research results were routinely reported to the NSF program director, and shared at national nd international conferences to introduce the scientific problem under consideration, to describe the datasets, and to encourage data scientists to get involved and examine the datasets.

The outcomes of the project can be used to provide research opportunities for data scientists from around the world. Given the complexity of the experiment and many technical challenges associated with neuroscience experiments, this project serves as a vehicle to speed up scientific discovery by involving many scientists through data sharing. The project may also attract attention from researchers who are not in the fields of neuroscience or neuroengineering per se, but are interested in studying big data in order to create more powerful mining algorithms for broad applications.

The project created a valuable training venue for students, both at graduate and undergraduate levels. Students were trained by getting involved in and contributing to cutting edge scientific research. Six undergraduate honors students worked regularly in the lab to assist animal training and handling. They acquired knowledge in behavioral and neural studies suing a rat model, and got involved in real-time problem solving. They had a unique chance to access exciting scientific research. Three graduate students worked on the project who learned to think systematically and creatively, ,to conduct electrophysioloical and  behavioral experiments using rats. The lab also trained several female students (one PhD student and two undergraduate students).

The PI and her students have attended national and international conference, gave tutorial talks and conference presentations, created web distribution of their neural data processing software (MSorter) to broadly disseminate their research results.
